SEARCH
Package org.bluezoo.gumdrop.http.client

Interface HTTPResponseHandler

All Known Implementing Classes:
DefaultHTTPResponseHandler
public interface HTTPResponseHandler
Handler interface for receiving HTTP response events.

This interface uses an event-driven pattern where response components are delivered incrementally as they arrive. This enables streaming processing of large responses and proper handling of HTTP trailer headers.

Event Flow

For a successful response with a body:

  1. ok(HTTPResponse) - status received
  2. header(String, String) - called for each response header
  3. startResponseBody() - body begins
  4. responseBodyContent(ByteBuffer) - called for each body chunk
  5. endResponseBody() - body complete
  6. header(String, String) - called for each trailer header (if any)
  7. close() - response complete

For a bodyless response (e.g., 204 No Content):

  1. ok(HTTPResponse) - status received
  2. header(String, String) - called for each response header
  3. close() - response complete

For an error response:

  1. error(HTTPResponse) - error status received
  2. header(String, String) - called for each response header
  3. (body events if the error response has a body)
  4. close() - response complete

For a connection failure:

  1. failed(Exception) - connection or protocol error

HTTP/2 Server Push

When an HTTP/2 server sends a PUSH_PROMISE, the pushPromise(PushPromise) callback is invoked. The handler can accept or reject the push. If accepted, a separate handler receives the pushed response.

Author:
Chris Burdess

  • Method Details

    • ok

      void ok(HTTPResponse response)
      Called when a successful response (2xx) status line is received.

      After this callback, header(String, String) will be called for each response header, followed by body events (if applicable), and finally close().

      Parameters:
      response - the response status

    • error

      void error(HTTPResponse response)
      Called when an error response (4xx, 5xx, or client-side pseudo-status) is received.

      This is called for HTTP error responses and client-detected conditions like

      invalid reference 
      HTTPStatus#REDIRECT_LOOP
      . The response may still have headers and a body (e.g., an HTML error page), which will be delivered via subsequent callbacks before close().
      Parameters:
      response - the error response

    • header

      void header(String name, String value)
      Called for each HTTP header received.

      Headers are delivered in the order they are received. This method may be called:

      • After ok(HTTPResponse) or error(HTTPResponse) for response headers
      • After endResponseBody() for trailer headers (HTTP/2 or chunked encoding)

      The same header name may appear multiple times for multi-value headers.

      Parameters:
      name - the header name (case may vary, compare case-insensitively)
      value - the header value

    • startResponseBody

      void startResponseBody()
      Called when the response body begins.

      This is not called for bodyless responses (e.g., 204 No Content, 304 Not Modified). After this callback, responseBodyContent(ByteBuffer) will be called for each chunk of body data, followed by endResponseBody().

    • responseBodyContent

      void responseBodyContent(ByteBuffer data)
      Called for each chunk of response body data.

      The buffer is only valid during this callback. If the data is needed later, it must be copied. The buffer's position and limit define the valid data range.

      Parameters:
      data - the body data chunk

    • endResponseBody

      void endResponseBody()
      Called when the response body is complete.

      After this callback, trailer headers (if any) may be delivered via header(String, String), followed by close().

    • pushPromise

      void pushPromise(PushPromise promise)
      Called when an HTTP/2 server push promise is received.

      The handler must either call PushPromise.accept(HTTPResponseHandler) to receive the pushed response, or PushPromise.reject() to cancel it. If neither is called, the push is rejected by default.

      This callback is only invoked for HTTP/2 connections.

      Parameters:
      promise - the push promise

    • close

      void close()
      Called when the response is fully complete.

      This is always the final callback for a successful response, called after all headers (including trailers) and body data have been delivered. After this callback, no further callbacks will be invoked for this response.

      This method is analogous to closing a stream or connection from the response handler's perspective.

    • failed

      void failed(Exception ex)
      Called when the request fails due to a connection error, protocol error, cancellation, or server shutdown (GOAWAY).

      This is the only callback invoked on failure. After this callback, no further callbacks will be invoked for this response.

      Common exceptions include:

      • ConnectException - connection refused
      • UnknownHostException - DNS failure
      • SSLException - TLS handshake failure
      • SocketTimeoutException - timeout
      • IOException - connection dropped
      • CancellationException - request cancelled
      Parameters:
      ex - the exception describing the failure
